document.text: M agnificent Reception. Court view, the handsome reside nee of Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Hunter jr, was the sene of a most cujoyable and entertaining reception and dance on Christmas night. The spacious parlors were fulled by nine, and by ten the dancing, which lasted until 2 oclock was begun after which time he guests took a reluctant leave of their hostess crying with them many pleasant reccollections of the Christmas night of 1894. The halls and large danceing rooms were ar tistically decorated with American beauties and evergreen. The Parlors were very beautiful clothed in mistletoe and Marschal Neils The dining hall was attractively trimmed in cedar and La France Roses. Mrs. Hunter the handsome hostest was assisted in receiving by Miss Georgie Morgan of Lynchburg and Misses Anna and Nina Jones of Appomattox. At 11 oclock the danceing was interrupted for a while by a magniflicent snpper served in manner agreeable toall. We notice a few of the numerous guests whose names and costumes we give alone. Mrs. C. document.text: Hop  and Supper at H otel A ppom attox. On the evening of July 27th there occurred an event which, for the en joyment of the moment and for the pleasant memories engendered,stands conspicuously eminent in the social annals of Appomattox. It was a hop given by the yonng men of our town. Concdrd, Spout Spring, Campbell, Prince Edward and Appo mattox furnished delegations of the most beautiful, and toilets of ex quisite and artistic taste. There was a lovely night with the fu ll moon shedding its mellow light, there were the sweet strains of music with the rythmic shuffling of dancing feet, and there was the merry talk and laughter of the gay participants, all combining to render the occasion pe culiarly enjoyable and a pronounced success. The future can contain nothing pleasanter than a repetition, and Appomattox may well say that for her to undertake is to succeed. The young ladies present and their toilets were as follows. Miss M. Anna Jones, lemon silk, trimmed in Irish point lace, passe menterie, no ornaments. Miss Nannie Wharton, white silk, lace trimmings. Miss Susie Jones, white crape, lace and diamonds. Miss Maggie Bevely, pink silk and natural flowers. Mrs. C. W. Hunter, black silk and white mulL Miss Slate OConner, albatross and point lace. Miss Nina Jones, orange silk,black point lace and diamonds. Miss Susie Evans, pink m ail, point lace and diamonds. Miss Sallie Arrington, cream silk and point lace. Miss Elma Shearer, white silk m all, and pearls. Miss Lula Peers, blue m ull, black lace, natural flowers, and diamonds. Miss Agnes Wooten, pink silk, natural flowers, and lace. Miss Erie Jones, white albatross, lace, and pearls. Miss Lucy Smith, blue mull,natu ral flowers. Miss Lina Davidson, white mnll and natural flowers. Mrs. Martin Harvey, white m ail, lace, and natural flowers. Miss Mattie Tweedy, pink lawn and point lace. Miss- Sallie Bnrke, white mull, natural flowers, and diamonds. Miss Maggie Smith, N ile green, natnriir flowers, no ornaments. Miss Lizzie Davidson, bine silk, natural flowers, no ornaments. Mrs. J. R. Atwood, black satin, point lace, and diamonds. Mrs. Lena Smith, white mnlL Miss Polly Main, black lace, rib bons, and natural flowers. Miss Florrie Arrington, cream silk, natural flowers, and point lace. Miss Viola Shearer, white alba tross, lace, and diamonds. Miss Sallie Ballou, white m ull and lace trimmings. Miss Phinizy Abbitt, white silk and lace t rim m ing. Miss Carrie Lee Davis, yellow crepon and rubies. The following ggbtlemen were present J. H. Bailey, Ewen Davidson, A. Dunn, H. G. Smith, Jno. Robertson, Edmund Miles, Frank McKinney, Clem Coleman, Taylor, W. W. Statham, Irby, J. Robertson, W. E. Doss, Wm. J. Trent, Collier Trent, G. W. Chockley, R. C. Harvey, Chap Jones, Wm. Moses, Boht. Watkins, Jno. M. Miles, Overton Nowlin, S. L. Ferguson, Dr. Julian Abbitt, Senator H. D. Flood. The gratitude of every one is due to qur kind host and hostess, Mr. and Mrs. Smith, who extended to the yonng people the well-known hospi talities of Hotel Appomattox, and who by their untiring efforts con tributed largely to the charming sncce88 of the occasion. Pam plin City B udget. The Baptists commenced a series of meetings at Hixbnrg on Sunday last. They are largely attended. Rev. Dr. Bagby, of Farmville, is as sisting the pastor, Rev. J. H. Conch, in the meetings. Misses Virginia Gilliam, and An nie McCraw, of Buckingham, are visiting at Mr. H. E. Gilliams. Rev. E. M. Craig returned to his charge at this place on the 31st nit., after a vacation of a month. Mr. C. S. McDearmon, night ope rator at yonr place, was in town to day. Mrs. Chancy, of Sntherlin, Va., is visiting at Mr. W. BL Rices. Mr. R. B. Green, of Richmond, is in town. P. H. E. Pkmplin City, Aug. 2.

document.text: D ies Sud d en ly a t H is H om e H ere Thursday. Dr. Julian Hamner Abbitt passed away at his residence here early Thursday morning, , suddenly. He bad been attending to bis profes sional duties all day, and was chat ting pleasantly with his family un til bed-time Wednesday night. About, midnight he compl-iined of feeling badly and bis wife and nephew attended him, and thought his c mdition satisfactory about 2 a. m. Thursday he was seized with a violent attack of indigestion and heart trouble and passed peacefully away in a short while. Thursday morning the news of his eath soon entered the homes of our people and without an ex ception the sorrow and gloom were perceptible everywhere. Business was suspended and sorrowing friends mingled their tears with the afflicted family around the lifeless body of tbeir physician aud friend. The deceased was in the 88 h year of his agein the prime of his life and was a splendid speci men of vigoroas manhood. He was a skilled physician, a friend to the poor, and a comfort to the afflicted and suffering. His practice was heavy, yet his love and devotion for -bis profession caused him to endnre many hardships and to work too hardtruly he died with his boots on, The rich and well-to-do will miss him, the afflicted poor sustains an irreparable loss, and the connty an upright, Christian gentleman. The deceased leaves to mourn his sadden death, besides his widow, who was Miss Sallie M. Ballou, of Halifax, aud four small children Frances, Edward, Juliau and Wil liam llenry, his aged father, Dr. W. H. Abbitt., and brothers. A. W. Ablnu, of Lynchburg, Bev. Geo. G. Abbitt, of Kentucky, JoUn D. Ab- biir, or Franklin, Va., E. R Abbitt and Dr J B. Abbitt of Appomat tox, and sistersMrs. G. A. Gole- mau and Miss Annie Abbitt of Appo attox. His body was prepared for burial and the funeral services were an- n u ced for Saturday iu order lo give relatives and friends from a distance an opportunity to attend. On.lurday evening tbe funeral took place from Liberty church, where be hud been a consistent member tor years aud was conduct ed by his pastor, Kev. Geo. Kenaard, assisted by Hevs, Hugh C. Smith, his former pastor, of Emporia, Va. H. T. Allison aud W. L. Murphy. The interrmeut was made at Liber ty cemetsry. A select choir from Lynchburg, assisted by local tilcut sang sweetly aud tenderly The Uhrisltaus Good Night aud Ab de wi ll Me. Tbe remarks of the pastors bearing upon the life of the deceased were tender and consoling to the bereaved audience. 7he family selected the follow ing pali-beurers and flower dealers

document.text: C h ild ren s H om e Society V irg in ia . The Childrens Home Society has been at work about 20 years. It was organized in Virginia only two years ago. In this comparatively short time many children have been rescued from a wretched fate, fittéd out in decent apparel and are now doing well in approved family home3. .The aim of the Society is 1. To find and obtain legal guar dianship of homeless children in Virginia. 2. To place these children in good family homes. 3. To see that the children thus, placed are not neglected or abused. 4. To save these children from pauperism aud crime, aud thus save the State from the grievous burden of taxation for their future care, aud from the danger of debased cit izenship arising from neglected childhood. The special features are 1. Systematic search for homes. 2. Constant outlook for depend ent and abused children, orphans, half orphans and worse than or phans. Many institutions do not take any but full orphans. 3. The Society has by law the gbt, with the sanction of the courts, to take children away from rossly cruel aud immoral parents. 4. Thorough organization, exten sive correspondence, distribution of literature, public addresses. 5. Strict economy, no costly build ings. Our aim is to place the child in a home with the least possible delay, in the meantime boarding them with some existing institution Rev. Wm. J. Maybee, the State Superintendent, was in West Appo mattox Sunday. He preached at the Methodist church in the morn ing and at Liberty Baptist at night. On this occasion there was a union service. All the pastors were pres ent. Mr. Maybee presented the claims and a local society was or ganized. Local Advisory Boards are organ ized in the centres of population to look after the interests of the Society in their respective communities, and report homeless children, and pass upon the character, social standing and financial ability of families in their neighborhood applying for children. The following were elected as our local board Messrs. S. L. Ferguson, A. H. Clement, J.R. Horsley and Dr. Julian Abbitt and Mesdames J. W. Flood, T. A. Smith and Ernest Gills. Miss Frances E. Willard, the philanthropist, said It is like all great discoveries, simple, practical, just the thing. We wonder where our wits were that we did not think of such a plan long ago. Persis tently followed out on a large scale, it will change the face of civiliza tion, cure poverty, kill out crime and bring forth the millenium. The work of the Society is pure charity. No charge is made for re ceiving a child or placing one in a family. All contributions are voluntary. All persons knowing of homeless or grossly abused children, and all persons who wish to take such children into their homes, should address Rev. Wm. J. Maybee, State Superintendent, Box 635, Richmond, Va., or see some member of the local board. The local organization o

document.text: The Concord uud W. Appomattox aorcgation appeared on the diamond for the first tijne this season iu practice game with Rustburg team last Saturday. Although the man ager of the home team was forced to appear against this up-to-date team with one scraped up anywhere he could get them, the Bustbnrg hoys didnt have t he cherry pie that they imagined. Chamberlayne te turned only that morning sick and broken down and was in no condi tion lo pitch, and he missed his last years catcher, Mr. Lee, who is now doing the tight rope and wire act in the Moore Family Indian show The Yellow Ball predominated throughout the game, and with  complete battery md regular pract ice the home team will lie more than h match for Rusthnrg or anv team on this road. Regular Kervices at Memorial Sunday Sunday school 10 a. m. and preaching 11 a m and 830 p. m. Special muic by choir. Everybody invited. Come and hear a good address A mass meeting is called for Saturday, 21st, to consider fur ther the road question in Ap pomattox county. If you are interested in good roads, better give the day and come out. Highway Commissioner Cole man is expected here. Several untaggedand seem ingly worthless  hound doge have been seen roaming around town right recently. The law says the tax must be paid on them or they must be killed July 1st is the last day of grace allowed their dogships. Mr. Edward Abbitt left today for Richmond, from whence he will go to China,xwhere he has accepted a position with the Export Tobacco Co. He will be gone four years. Edward is the oldest son of the late Dr Julian Abbitt of this place. The  song of the cradle and the reaper is heard on every side now and a generous whea crop is promised. The returned soldiers to the farms lessened the shortage of labor, and w p have heard ot no complaint due to labor shortage, which war not th e case last year.

document.text: I d M em ortani FRANCES BRANSFOBD ABBITT ROSE j ust at daws of September nineteenth, uinteen hundred and twenty-two, tne spirit of Frances Brauaford Abbitt Rose took its flight trom its earthly abode to her heavenly home, at St. Lukes hospital, Richmond, Va , where she had been ill foi a month. Frances Abbitt Rose was the only daughter of toe late Dr Julian Hamner Abbiti of Appomattox, Va , and Bailie Ballou Abbitt, who survives her, also two brothers Edwaid Ballou Abbitt, of Shangha, China, and Julian Abbitt, of U. a N In August, nineteen eigi teen, Frances was marneo to Mr. John Daniels Rose, oi Henderson, N. C., who surviv es her with three small children. Of a bright and happy dispo sitiOD, she easily made friends and was greatly beloved by a large circle of relatives and friends. She was so fair and young, do happy in ministering to ih- needs of her husband aud chil dren, so contented in her home, always counting it her greatest joy to be with her little family, that her seemingly untimely yassing cast a gloom over the entire community in which she lived Sue was a faithful and oyai member of t h e Episcopal church and ever ready to do what she could to further its interests. Truly, her sorrowing loved ones feelthat to Frances there was one clear call as she  put out to sea aDd mat her Filot face to face. Her body was brought to Henderson and tenderly bom by those near and dear to her was laid to rest under a bank of flowers. yAs the wotds of the burial service, so full of significance, read by Dr. Housfeld, fell upon the .ears of the grief-stricken husband and relatives they said iu their hearts  Behold, she is n jt here she is risen. She is with the redeemed, with love ones gone before,and lives, as we love to believe, to be still a ministering spirit.  Father in Thy gracious keep- ing, Leave we now our Frances sleeping. One Who Loved Her.

Work on the new Appomat tox tobacco factory is progress ing satisfactorily. Mr. and Mrs. T. 8. Bridges, of Crewe, spent the week end in the home of Capt. Gahliar. Mias E la Porter, of Lynch burg, is visiting her cousin, Miss Elizabeth Smith. Mrs Sarah E Collins, of Danville, is visiting Mrs. J. T. Cola Counie Odor, of Lynchburg, was visiting his brothers here last week Miss Maymee Chockl tte, of Lvnchbug, spent Sunday with Miss Ilene Smith. Mr Havilah Babcock is at tending summer school work at University of Virginia. Mrs. Leland Morris and chil dren, of Richmond, are visiting relatives here. Mr.. N H Gregory is on a visit to her son, Leonard, in Portsmouth, Ohio. Mr. and Mrs A H. Gregory are on an extended trip to Cal ifornia. Miss Vara Silas, of Norfolk, Va.. is the guest of Mies Rheda Drinkard this week  Miss Eva Woolridge has re turned home after a visit to relatives in Lynchburg. Mr. A E. Jones, of Lynch Imrg, was a visitor here this week to his family. Mr. King David Beasley was in this town Monday He is now living in Amherst county Miss Ilene Smith is visiting her aunt, Mrs. W. J. Walton at Rent Creek, Va. Misses Gladys-- Smith and Pearl Caldwell left last week for Harrisonburg,to attend sum mer normal. Misses Flora and Ruby Will iam, of ram plin, spent the week end with Miss Gladys Smith. Mr A. Burl abb tt, of New port News, is bail ling a nice residence at Vera, his old home. Mr W. B. Harvey is here to day making arrangements with field secretary for the County Sunday-school convention Mrs. A. B. Reynolds and children, of Louisville, Miss , are visiting Mrs. C. F. James here. Mr. W. H. Burke, wife and children, of Roanoke, are visit ing in the home of Col. R F. Burke There will be a regular meet ing of the Eastern S ar Friday night, the 2ad, at 730 Mrs. Li. E Smith, S bc Mr. Berkley Woolridge and sister, Odelle, of Lynchburg, spent Sunday with their pa rents, Mr. and Mrs. W. S Woolridge. Mrs. Julian Abbitt, who has been visiting her daughter in North Carolina, came home v e e t e r d a v , and is reported sick together with her son, Billy Misses Caroline Hunter and Grace Adams, of Lynchburg, are house guests at tne country home of Miss Dean Johns near here. Mr. W. T. Coleman and fami ly were in town Saturday. Bascom, his s o d , of Bluafield, W. Va , is spending his vaca tion at nome. Mr. Hunter Smith and daugh ter, Miss Josephine, returned to Fayetteville, N C , last week after a visit to friends and rela tives here ,  accompanied by Miss Margaret Hancock. document.text: Glenfall. The birds have begun to sing, the frogs to croak, flowers are bloom ing, grass is growing, consequently we are encouraged to think that the Winter of our discontent isover, and very gladly do we weioome the approach cf spring. Mr. Orman Jones visisted his aunts near here recently, and invested extensively in jewelry at Mr. J. W. Harveys store. Miss Verona Bell has gone to Prospect to visit Mr. and Mrs. Broadus Scruggs, who have been ill with pneumonia. Mr. Herny Hamersley, who has been very sick, is now much better. Dr. Julian Abbitt attended him. MissWillie Bell is visiting relatives and freinds near Carsons Mill. Ae o.ir pastor was providentially absent at Mt. Comfort the first 3uuday, we looked forward with much eagerness to his coming on third Sabbath, anu though it was an ideal day, we were doomed to dis appointment, as he said March was winter month, and he was not expected. There is danger of our going into a state of heathenism, as there have been no pastors at the Baptist and Pres, churches, and now two months will intervene between the.services at Mt. Comfort. Mr. S. G. Payne visited his wife and son near here recently. Frequent rains have greatly retard ed farm worksowing oats and clover seed will now be in order, though some were fortunate to get their clover seed in before the fre quent showers. Wheat looks wtll and clover and timothy are growing rapidly. Hauling of ties has been suspended owing to the callin. of a halt by tb- N.  W. Ry. Your readers were delighted that the Audersouvilie correspondent has awakened from his Rip Van Winkle sleep, and now we hope that some thing, even if it be a broom stick will keep him awake and thereby brighten your columns more fre quently. Misses Ida and Neal Jones are vis iting their brotuer near Spout Spring. Master Mosby H. Payne sold Lis crop of tobacco in Lynchburg last week. It was his first crop and as it brought so little, he seems thor oughly discouraged, nod will not at tempt another crop of the trouble some weed. When this reaches your sanctum it may bi snowing. This latter paragraph may be hatd on the mail service.E d .

document.text: from the observation either of his own family or of persons who might pass along the road. Mrs. Nowlin went out on the porch and gave the alarm, and requested Constable N. W. Owen to arrest Mr. Nowlin, say ing that be had twice shot at her. Heury, a sou of Mr. Nowlin, came up, and went in search of his lather. He found him behind an outhouse. Mr. Nowlin said to him  Get my horse. I want you to carry me to Spout Spring. He spoke so ration ally that the young mau left him to go to the field and take a horse from the plow for bis fathers use in go ing to Spout Spring. Before leav ing his father, Heury tequested him to give up the pistol which he had concealed on his person. Mr. Now lin was searched, but no pistol was found. His son had proceeded ouly a few steps when Mr. Nowlin sent u bullet through his own brain. He eeled aud fell, and died within 30 minutes. The bullet entered his left temple and came out just above his right car. Diligent inquiry has not developed any cause whatever for the rasl. act of Mr. Nowlin, and, al though he was of a despondent dis position and very high-tempered, he had never had an attack that made him the mudmau he was on Friday. Those nearest to him claim that he was evidently cruzy, aud that is the general verdict of the people. He nad for years beeen a great sufferer from ueuralgia and his bodily health was generally rather infirm. Borne reports say that Mr. Nowlin became enraged at a negro servant on the place, and had no occasion to be an gry with his wife, who is one of the best ladies in our county. It is one of the saddest affairs that ever hap pened in this county, as the family upon both sides is well known and highly connected. The deceased was born about 62 years ago in the house in which he was piepared for burial. He was not a member of any church. While he was high-tempered and courageous, he had a warm heart, full of sympathy. He had beeu a merchant and postmaster at Oak ville most of his life, but was engaged in farming at the. time of his death. Besides his wife, who was a Miss Woodson, Mr. Now lin leaves six children. He is also survived by two brothers and two sisters Mr. S. Walker Nowlin, of Lynchburg Mr. William S. Nowlin, of Spout Spring Mrs. Samuel H. Overton, of Spout Spring and Mrs. John Hughes, of Oakville. His burial took place on Saturday even ing, at the family burying ground on the place, and was quite largely attended by friends of the family. Evergreen. We have had another fine rain. Crops are looking very well. The wheat is very good all through this part of the county. There is some complaint about the oats turning yellow in some places. The tobacco crop in general is rather small, but is growing well, and nearly every body has a good stand. The corn is looking green and is growing well. The crops of clover and grass are not of much account There are about 75 railroad men now at work here. - Alost of t.heni spend their nights in our village, anu it is something of a sight to see them come in at night. The mer chants report good sales now, espe cially of cider. They cant keep a supply of that equal to the demand. We are sorry to learn that little Gerard Davis is still very ill. Drs. Julian Abbitt and Walker are both attending him. Mr. Walter Davis has again been called to his bedside. Mrs. Sue Harvey continues very ill at her home near this place. Mrs. Ed. Hamilton has been call ed home in great haste to attend her husband, who is very ill of fever. Mrs. Nat. Gregory last week spent several days visiting her husband in and around this place. She won many friends by her pleasant man ners and sweet ways. We heartily hope that she had a pleasant visit, and that she will come again. Mr. N. H. Gregory left on Mon day for the Hill City. Mr. Geo. Carter, of High Bridge, was in our town on Monday. Mr. James Suliivan and his little daughter Eliza spent several days in Lynchburg last week.

document.text: Evergreen. There is a scarcity of news this week. We have damn weather a plenty but not much rain as yet. The workmen are busy engaged in finishing up the tank. - The picnic at the Rocks was a grand succcess. There was a plenty to take home after leeding the larg- crowd ever seen theie on such The recitations were splendid, couldnt have been better. The manner in which the children were trained reflects great credit on he young ladies, Misses Carrie Caw- thorn and Lillie Dawson. The protracted meeting is iu pro gress at Rocks. Rev. P. T. Warren, the prstor, assisted by Rev. Luther Warren. The weather is so threat ening that the crowds are small. We wish them much success in their meeting. Messrs. Norman Dawson and Payne, of Pampliu City, are in our village this a. m. Miss Elma McDe,rmou left this place to-day for Burkville, where she will atteod school. She is a sweet little girl and we hate to give her up. She has our best wishes. Mr. Bennie Inge, of Roanoke, is at home this week attending the Rocks meeting. We are always glad to have him with us. Mrs. Ed. Bates and Miss Alice Whitaker, of Spout Spring were among those that attended the Rocks picnic Saturday. Bennie Rakes, of Farmville, is here relieving Mr. H. C. Farrar who is attending the Rock meeting this week. Dr. Julian Abbitt operated ott Mrs. Joe Inges foot to-day. She is resting very quietly. We wish her a speedy recovery. Willie McDearmon is this week the guest of his brother, Mr. Lucy McDearmon of Burkeville.

document.text: Evergreen.  during the high wind that lasted for three days last week mnch for-  ago which had been stacked up was blown down. Rev. Wm, L. Bediuger filled his appointment here on Snnday night. There was not a large congregation. Mr. Staples still conducts prayer meeting on every Wednesday night, and will be glad to see as many pre sent as can possibly come. Do not stay away just because the weather is getting cool, as there are two good stoves in the church. We regret to say that Mr. George Glover is again worse. He has been ill for five long weeks. Mrs. Hunter Martin has for three wei-ks been suffieeing severely from,a joint-felon on her right hand. Dr. W. H. Abbitt Is attending her. Mr. Joe Inge is this week some what better. He has for several days been very ill from stomach trouble. Dr. E. E. Walker, of Pamplin City, was called to attend him. Mrs. Deloca Cheatham, of Bartow, Florida, left to-day, after a stay qf about four months. She aud her three bright boyst will be greatly missed. Cards are ont for the marriage of Mr. Thomas Cheatham, of Miami, Florida, to take place on October 28. We wish for this noble young man a long life of prosperity and happi ness, even if he did forget to send us a bid. Mr. 0. S. McDerrmon will in the near future enlarge his store so that he can handle dry goods. Lumber for the work is now in place. Mr. iawson Wooldrige, of Bine lidge Springs, was in oar town on Sunday, and looking as handsome as vèr, so one of his best girls said, 1 Mr. John Jennings has gone back o bis work. We hope that ho will continue to improve. Miss Marjory Meadernach has re turned to her home in Danville. She left some sad hearts and long faces n old Appomattox. Miss Maude Ragland has returned to ber home, after a pleasant visit of several weeks in Nelson county, etc. She is looking well. Mrs. Hunter Glenn and her bro- her, Mr. Bennie Inge, of Roanoke, who have lately been with their sick father, have returned to their home. Bennie left bis fine horse and buggy with his father. We are grieved to learn of the ill- nous of Dr. Julian Abbitt. Wé earn- ly pray that God in His goodness wtil spare him, aud that he -may soph recover. October 13, 1903.

document.text: Evergreen. - Died at the home of his adopted parents, Mr. Satnl and Sackey Dickerson, near old Rocks church August 16th, C h a r l ie M c R o y . For eight days he was a great suf ferer, dying with that awful disease diptheria. No human ever suf fered moredeath was a great re liefpoor little orphan, we hope he is safe in heaven with his mother who died when he was a babe. Saml McDearmon, a worthy ool- ored man of our vicinity had the misfoi tune to have his house burned down on last Friday night vyith all its contents. No one can tell the origin of the fire unless a lamp ex ploded that was left burning when the family left to visit a sick friend. Daniel has the sympathy of white and colored in his loss. We are glad to learn that Mr. Col lier Trent has rented Mr. Davis store and will open lip in the near future. We all extend our best wishes to him and we will be glad to welcome such a popular young merchant iu our town, Miss Carrie Cawthorn who has been very ill for two weeks is rap- dly improving under the skillfull treatment of Dr. Julian Abbitt.

T imes see that I am as deeply inter ested in the paper as ever, only I cant always find time to write, though dont guess my uninteresting letter is missed much. The Club last Saturday uight qt the home of Mr. W. J. McDearmon was well attended, and all present. seemed to have a good time. It was invited to meet at the home of Mr. E. H. Cawthorn next Saturday night. There is lots of sickness in our village nowsome one sick at most every house in the place. Among those sick are Mr. W. 0. Farrar, Mr. Jim Hamilton, Mr. Basoom Thorn ton, aud Wiley Hauoook, a colored boy lrom West Va. Dr. Julian. Ab- bitt is- attending them, and theii many friends hope to soou see then, out again. .  Mr. Hector O hw tie rn, of iortf mouth, Ohio, who is visiting his pu rents here, left for Ienipliu Git, yesterday to see his best girl, accbm panied by bis chanting sister, Misr Ella. - Messrs. Nathan and Lawson Wool-  dridge visited the Hill City Iasi  week. There have been nine cases of pueuuionia in our village since the first of.last fall, and the doctors lost only oue casethat of Mr. Ragland. We are glad to say Mr. Barrel! Gralle was not seriously injured by the ruuaway horse last week. Al of his brothers hastened to his side and found him better, and went back to their work happy. Mr. E. H. Cawthorn made a busi ness trip to Lynchburg aud Roanoke last week. Little Harry Rtigland is much better, we are glad to say. Miss Willie Wool ridge is now suf fering with some disease of the throat. Her many friends hope it is nothing serious. Many a prayer is being made for the recovery of Mr. Jim Hamilton, he lies dangerously ill at bis store hers. His mother, relatives and friends are at his bed-side, and Dr. JuHan Abbitt sees him daily. Remember prayer meeting every Wednesday night 715. document.text: And Cotillion Party at Concord Depot. The Editor of jhis paper, in com pany with others, left on the 4i08 N . A W. train yesterday for Concord, where they had been previously in vited to participate in a sociable at thè most hospitable residence of xrs. X. Wharton. A t 7.30 oclock p. m., the company, numbering in all about thirty ladies and gentlemen Repaired to the spacious dining-room, where a sumptuous repast was partaken of and enjoyed by all present. The hostess, Mrs. Wharton, received the well-deserved credit from all who partook of the bountiful supply with which the table was heavily ladened. THE HOP. The young men after consultation among themselves, decided to have a social hop, and after securing the services of Prof. Steele the party repaired to the hall where they tripped the light fantastic toe to the sweet music discoursed by the above- named gentleman, till the wee sma hours of the morn, when each par ticipant took leave for their respect ive homes, feeling perfectly satisfied with the evenings entertainment. Following are the names of the ladies and gentlemen who partici pated in the dance Miss Lola Elliott, Lynchburg, Va. 6 Muriah Shanks, Salem, Va.  Lelia Shanks,    Nannie Wharton, CopooriL  E. P. document.text: A Delightful Dance. The Tepsichorean Club, composed bf the young ladies of the town, gave one of their charming dances at Hotel Appomattox on Tuesday night. Owing to the inclemency of the weather, thè attendance was smaller than was expected, but those who were so fortunate as to be pres ent will not soon forget it. .The dancing commenced about 9 oclock and continued until some time after midnight. There waB an intermis sion, during which, those in attend ance partook of a delightful. repast. The consensus of opinion was that it was a decided success and will hear repetition. Following are the names of those present Misses Anna Jones, Rosa Wheeler, Sallie Burke, Carrie Smith, Polly Main, Eddie Hardy, Lucy Smith, Maggie Smith and Emma Smith. Mesdames I. O. Abbitt, W. J. document.text: Celebrating the tenth anni versary of the signing of the armistice which virtually brought to a close the great World War, Rev. W. M. Thompson will preach a special patriotic sermon i at Liberty Baptist church Sun day, November 11th, at 8 p. m. Patriotic hymns will be sung and a special number will be rendered by a mixed quartet. The follow ing names of men who served their country during the World War are found on the Liberty Church Honor Roll W. Ernest Abbitt, Russell Abbitt, Thos. H. Agee, Clarence Agee, W. Patt Coleman. John - Garter, J Oscar Cole, Thos. E. Caldwell, Richard Caldwell, Walter E. Durham, Terry C. Durham, G. Lewis Doss. Albert H. Ferguson, Thos. J- Ferguson, Kenneth Furbush, Leonard N. Th-i county fair three weeks off a for it? The white schools are all open in running order. Mrs. J. W. Carter, has the Wildway to Liberty Chapel school wagon again this yearThornton Car ter has the one from Wildway to Vera. Julian Grow, who has been working in Lynchburg all mer, is back home. Mrs. Grow, of Roanoke, visiting her horne people. Messrs. Jeff Kinney and R. A. Steffans who went through the terrible storm at Miami, Fla., and escaped unharmed, are visit ing their parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. W. Kinney, for a few days, while conditions are improving in that water-soaked country they tell some thrilling incidents of what occured during those twelve long hours of howling wind and driving rain. Miss Susie and Olivia Booker, who have been visiting their parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Booker, at Tower Hill, have re turned to Richmond. George Booker, of Tower Hill, is attending school at Pamplin. Mr. John Beale, who was car ried to a Lynchburg hospital, was brought back last week. We are sorry to learn Mr. Beale is not improving as his friends would wish. Mrs. Lou Ferguson who has been an invalid for more than a year had a bad spell Saturday but is better at this writing. Mr. John Everette Childers, who has been suffering from an infected hand is improving right along, now, we are glad- to re port. Mrs. Jerome Menefee left for Richmond Saturday, to spend the winter With her son, J. T. Menefee and family. Miss Christine Garrett is at tending school at Harrisonburg. Messrs. Watkins and George Abbitt haver gone to Richmond to attend college, and Miss Dora Abbitt is attending A. A. H. S. at Appomattox Mrs. Mayne, who has visiting relatives here, left for Washing ton last week. The farmers are busy cutting and housing tobaccothey are antic pating a visit from Jack Frost in the near future. Sir Leon Levison, president of the International Christian He brew Alliance, in a speech in Toronto, declared that in Hun gary, there are at least forty thousand Jews, who believe in Christ in Poland, thirty-five thousand awhile in Norway, Den mark and Sweeden, fully four- fifths of the entire Jewish popu lation believe in Him. Mr. Stanley Baldwin, Prime Minister of Britain, said recent lyMany forces of good and of evil were loosed in 1914, forces that were not bound at the time of the Armistice and there is a strange leaven at work, today, among all the nations of the world. The Gentile Times ended in 1914. Mr. Baldwin is beginning to see some of the signs of the new dispensation Christs kindom now being ush ered in. Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Booker announce the marriage of their daughter, Marie Susie to Mr- William Dinguid Christian, on Saturday, September 25th, at Washington, D. C- These young people were born and raised in this neighborhood and have a host of friends who wish them God Speed, blessings and happi ness through life. They will be at home at 80 Ridgeway Terrace, Cumberland, Md.

document.text: By order of the Electorial Board of Appomattox County, all Regis tration Books in Southside District shall be purged as of October 4 1954. The names listed below have been removed from the Registration Books, Courthouse Precinct, South- side District, Appomattox County Virginia for reasons of death transferred or moved. This action is provided for and ordered under Sec tions 24-94 through 24-107 of the Virginia Election Laws as amend ed. Our special Washington cor respondent says of him The death of Flood is directly due to his fine devotion to his State and partv When tbs Republicans gave it out that they were going to break into the solid South and that Vir ginia was to be the gateway, everyone knew that it meant another loosening of the strings of the long purse that poured out millions and millions for the election of Harrison, Me Kinley, Roosevelt, Taft and Hardingthe long purse of privilege. The Virginia leaders looked over the field and could see no one but Flood to lea the fight to prevent the Repub licans again getting a foothold in the State that was still re- membring painfully the days of the carpet baggers So Flood wae drafted for the iob, though already Chairman of the Demo cratic Congressional Commit tee, he went into it like he went into every other fight with every ounce of force there was in him Of course he wod , aud the Democrats carried Vir ginia by the biggest majority ever known, but Flood came back to Washington and took to hi bed, never to leave it. Of him it can be truly said  He died with the harness on, the broad sword leaping, the wild fight surging fast  Rich as the party is in leadership, Democracy can ill spare him, this proud Virginian, proud of his clean hands, his clean pub tic record, Lis clean profession al career and his spotless personal character. It is re membered of bim that when he first came t j Congress, defeat ing Jacob Yost, a Republican, the result was very close ano he was offered the certificate of election on. a technicality, wbereu ton be refused to accept it, preferring to stand aside until the status of every ques cioned ba lot wae determined, be knew he might lose by so doing, but be preferred it that way. The folio wiug tribute paid our distinguished countyman by a life-long friend is worthy of both men Nobody seems to be able to realize chat Hal Flood, of Ap pomattox, is dead. We cannot grasp the fact that the mao of vigor and force and activity upon wuern we Had learned to rely, and under whose devoted watch care we had learned to feel secure has been suddenly called from his earthly duties, ank that our friend is no more. Mr. Floods great abilities and worth in public life were uaiversaly recognized. But to the people of Appomattox nr was held in esteem as nowhere else, because it was here that tiis worth in private life was best known. Many years

document.text: Mrs. Lovella McGuire and daughter, Betty Dale, and Mrs. Sallie Minchner, of Richmond, spent Sunday with their brother, G. B. Buchanan and Mrs. Bucha nan. The Buchanans took their guests on a tour of the National Park Area and then had picnic lunch at the Memorial Bridge.    Mrs. Shearer Robertson, Mrs. Ann Davis and Mr. W. H. Ro bertson returned last week from Tennessee. Mrs. Robertson and Mrs. Davis motored to Missouri and Arkansas while there.    Lt. and Mrs. G. Moses Din kins spent a few days with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Dinkins. Lt. Dinkins was en route from Texas to Fort Mead, Md., where he will be stationed.    Mrs. W a t k i ns Abbitt and daughters, Rinne, and Mrs. Sami Kerr, of Richmond, are spend- j ing this week at Virginia Beach.    Miss Dot Sears joined friends from Petersburg Wednesday for a trip to Nova Scotia.    Mr. and Mrs. Preston Coleman visited his sisters, Mrs. R. N. Spiggle, Mrs. Irvin C. Moses and Miss Kate Coleman Monday afternoon.    Mrs. Julian Guill and daugh-1 ter, Julia Ann, are visiting re-1 latives in Philadelphia.   m Mrs. Charlie Page visited her i sisters, Mr. Irvin C. Moses and Miss Kate Coleman on Monday, j July 20th.    Judge and Mrs. George Abbitt,  Jr. and daughter, Nancy R ep.! and Mrs. Watkins M. Abbitt and  daughter, Rinne, and Mr. and j Mrs. Ed Cawthorne attended the  annual meeting of the Common wealths Attorney association at the Cavalier Hotel in Virginia Beach over the week end.    Mrs. William B. Brown and children have returned to their home in Cincinnati after a two weeks vacation with Mr s . Browns mother, Mrs. Sue G. Johnston.    Mrs. Sue G. Johnston has re turned home after spending a week with her daughter and family, Mrs. W. A. Hickman, De catur, Illinois.    Recent guests of Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Shuford have been many of Mr. Shufords relatives of Florida. Also friends Mr. and Mrs. Carl Carter and Mr. and Mrs. Hermie Kelly also of Starke Fla.    Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bugg, Hugh and Nadine spent a recent week end visiting in Richmond.    Mr. and Mrs. R. G. Holt, Mrs. W. R. Holt, of Pamplin, Mrs. Wm C. Gaines, of Detroit, Mich., Mrs. J. R. Shuford and Mrs. Murrell Ferguson attended the funeral of Mr. Thomas Price Samuel in Petersburg Monday morning, July 20th. Mr. Samuel is Mrs. W. R. Holts brother-in- law.    Mrs. J. R. Shuford and Mrs. William C. Gaines attended the  dedication services of the new Patrick Henry Boys Cottage at Red Hill, Charlotte C o u n t y , Thursday afternoon, July 23.    Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Carson, Mr. and Mrs. Tommie Carson and family, and Mrs. Hazel Wertz, all of Roanoke, visited Mrs. David W. Smith and moth er, Mrs. J. O. Robertson, last week.    Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Thornhill, who have been making their home in Norfolk have moved to Brooklyn, N.Y. En route to New York they visited relatives in the county several days.    J. O. Robertson is recovering nicely in the Virginia Baptist Hospital where he underwent surgery.

document.text: March 28  Miss Jean Brown is home from Averett College for the Spring, semester. David Austin returned home last week from the hospital. We hope he may soon be well. Little Denise Webb spent the week end with her grandparents Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Webb. document.text: Feb. 14  Mr. and Mrs. Julian Jenkins, of Lynchburg, visited his mother and sister, Mrs. Addie Jenkins and Mrs. Ber Abbitt, Saturday. We are so glad Mrs. Jenkins is some better at this writing. Mr. D. L. Smith is on the sick list. We missed him at Holly wood, Sunday. Mr. Joe Slough was brought home from the hospital, Sunday afternoon. We all wish for him a speedy recovery. His daughter, Mrs. Edith Soudens, of Balti more, is spending a few days with her parents. Howard Smith is on the sick list. We hope he may soon be well again. Mr. and Mrs. R. H. Coleman called in the C. J. Bagby home, Friday afternoon. Mrs. Ralph Robinson visited Mr. and Mrs. L. H. document.text: By order of the Electoral Board of Appomattox County, Virginia, all Registration Books in Stonewall Dis trict shall be purged as of October 4, 1954. The names as listed below have been removed from the Regis tration Books, Stonewall Precinct, Stonewall District, Appomattox County, Virginia for reasons of death, transferred or moved. This action is provided for and ordered under Sections 24-94 through 24- 107 of the Virginia Election Laws as amended. Any one who can prove conclus ively that any of the names listed below have a right to be on the Re gistration Books of said county of said district, they shall make such information available to the under signed registrar.
